SubTopics: Analyze in detail how an author's ideas or claims are developed and refined by particular sentences, paragraphs, or larger portions of a text (e.g., a section or chapter).
Content: In ‚ÄúSnapping an Iconic Photo,‚Äù how does paragraph 3 contribute to the development of the passage?

A.Choice: It suggests Lange's anxiety about being on a deserted road.

B.Choice: It shows Lange's curiosity about what pea pickers did during the day.

C.Choice: It describes a critical moment that contributed to Lange taking a famous photograph.

D.Choice: It establishes a contrast between the different regions of California through which Lange was driving.

SubTopics: Determine the meaning(s) of words and phrases as they are used in a text, including figurative, connotative, and technical meanings; analyze the cumulative or contradictory impact of specific word choices on meaning and tone (e.g., how the language of a court opinion differs from that of a newspaper; how an author's word choice varies from one part of a text to another).
Content: Which statement ùóïùóòùó¶ùóß describes the irony expressed in paragraphs 8 and 9 of ‚ÄúThe Story of the 'Migrant Mother'‚Äù?

A.Choice: Thompson was the focus of other photographs, but no one ever noticed her in them.

B.Choice: Thompson's children grew up to lead successful lives, yet they were unable to support her.

C.Choice: Thompson was finally recognized for the photograph, but she was too busy to appreciate it.

D.Choice: Thompson's image was supposed to aid people in situations similar to hers, yet she gained nothing from it.

SubTopics: Analyze how an author unfolds an analysis or series of ideas or events, including the order in which the points are made, how they are introduced and developed, and the presence or absence of connections between them.
Content: Which statement ùóïùóòùó¶ùóß describes how the authors of ùóïùó¢ùóßùóõ passages present their information?

A.Choice: They both provide the context in which Lange took the photograph followed by reflections on its impact.

B.Choice: They both compare Lange's memories of taking the photograph with Thompson's memories of having posed for it.

C.Choice: They both describe the appearances of Lange and Thompson in order to emphasize the differences in their lifestyles.

D.Choice: They both describe some of the issues that led to the Great Depression in order to contrast them with the beauty of Lange's work.

SubTopics: Determine a central idea of a text and analyze its development over the course of the text, including how it emerges and is shaped and refined by specific details; provide an objective summary of a text.
Content: Read the sentences from ‚ÄúSnapping an Iconic Photo‚Äù and ‚ÄúThe Story of the 'Migrant Mother'‚Äù in the box.

:box:‚Ä¢ As she drove back toward Highway 101 that day, Lange may have realized that she had not asked for her subject's name. In fact, she would never find out. (paragraph 15 of ‚ÄúSnapping an Iconic Photo‚Äù)

‚Ä¢ No one even knew her name: Lange never asked, and by the time the photo appeared in a local newspaper, the woman and her family had moved on to the next town. (paragraph 3 of ‚ÄúThe Story of the 'Migrant Mother'‚Äù)
What conclusion can be drawn from the sentences?

A.Choice: Lange attempted to maintain a closeness to the people she worked with.

B.Choice: Lange's photographs were different from her recollections of the events.

C.Choice: Lange tried to be as efficient as possible when completing her assignments.

D.Choice: Lange's photographs represented something greater than the individuals who were in them.

SubTopics: Determine an author's point of view or purpose in a text and analyze how an author uses rhetoric to advance that point of view or purpose.
Content: Which statement ùóïùóòùó¶ùóß describes a major difference between the authors' purposes in ‚ÄúSnapping an Iconic Photo‚Äù and ‚ÄúThe Story of the 'Migrant Mother'‚Äù?

A.Choice: ‚ÄúSnapping an Iconic Photo‚Äù focuses on conveying historical facts, while ‚ÄúThe Story of the 'Migrant Mother'‚Äù tries to tell an entertaining story.

B.Choice: ‚ÄúSnapping an Iconic Photo‚Äù relates an encounter from Lange's perspective, while ‚ÄúThe Story of the 'Migrant Mother'‚Äù tries to create sympathy for Thompson.

C.Choice: ‚ÄúSnapping an Iconic Photo‚Äù describes Lange's and Thompson's personality traits, while ‚ÄúThe Story of the 'Migrant Mother'‚Äù highlights their accomplishments.

D.Choice: ‚ÄúSnapping an Iconic Photo‚Äù describes techniques used to take photographs, while ‚ÄúThe Story of the 'Migrant Mother'‚Äù explains the influence of photographs.

SubTopics: Determine or clarify the meaning of unknown and multiple-meaning words and phrases based on grades 9‚Äì10 reading and content, choosing flexibly from a range of strategies.

:box:So she organized her posture and set her expression just so for Lange's camera. And that is a talent, too. Thompson and Lange, for an instant in 1936, were collaborators.
Based on the sentences, what does the word collaborators mean?

A.Choice: friends

B.Choice: partners

C.Choice: assistants

D.Choice: advocates

Topics: Informational Text - Integration Of Knowledge & Ideas
SubTopics: Analyze seminal documents of historical and literary significance (e.g., Washington's Farewell Address, Lincoln's Second Inaugural and Gettysburg Addresses, Roosevelt's Four Freedoms speech, King's ‚ÄúLetter from Birmingham Jail‚Äù), including how they address related themes and concepts.
Content: Answer Part A and Part B for this question.
What idea is presented in ùóïùó¢ùóßùóõ passages?

A.Choice: heritage

B.Choice: hardship

C.Choice: hardship

D.Choice: companionship

Content: Choose the set of details that ùóïùóòùó¶ùóß support the answer to Part A.

A.Choice:
‚ÄúThe driver, 40-year-old professional photographer Dorothea Lange, sat alone in the car.‚Äù (paragraph 1 of ‚ÄúSnapping an Iconic Photo‚Äù)

‚ÄúThompson was born Florence Leona Christie, a Cherokee, in a teepee in Indian Territory, Oklahoma, in 1903.‚Äù (paragraph 5 of ‚ÄúThe Story of the 'Migrant Mother'‚Äù)

B.Choice:
‚ÄúAs she drove along the nearly deserted road, Lange suddenly saw something interesting.‚Äù (paragraph 3 of ‚ÄúSnapping an Iconic Photo‚Äù)

‚ÄúThe crop had been destroyed by freezing rain; there was nothing to pick.‚Äù (paragraph 1 of ‚ÄúThe Story of the 'Migrant Mother'‚Äù)

C.Choice:
‚ÄúA woman and four children sat beneath a crude tent with one side open to the elements.‚Äù (paragraph 11 of ‚ÄúSnapping an Iconic Photo‚Äù)

‚ÄúThere is no help, no protection, and nothing over the horizon but work, want and more wandering.‚Äù (paragraph 2 of ‚ÄúThe Story of the 'Migrant Mother'‚Äù)

D.Choice:
‚ÄúBy the time Lange reached a cluster of small tents and makeshift shelters, the rain had tapered off.‚Äù (paragraph 11 of ‚ÄúSnapping an Iconic Photo‚Äù)

‚ÄúIn the years to follow, the Thompson family kept their identities to themselves, but the photograph was a continual subject of conversation.‚Äù (paragraph 7 of ‚ÄúThe Story of the 'Migrant Mother'‚Äù)

SubTopics: Analyze how an author unfolds an analysis or series of ideas or events, including the order in which the points are made, how they are introduced and developed, and the presence or absence of connections between them.
Content: Reread paragraphs 7 and 8 of ‚ÄúThe Story of the 'Migrant Mother.'‚Äù Which ùóßùóõùó•ùóòùóò details provide evidence that Thompson acted selflessly?

A.Choice: ‚ÄúShe managed to get the car towed into the Nipomo pea-pickers camp, had it repaired, and was just about to leave when Dorothea Lange appeared.‚Äù (paragraph 7)

B.Choice: ‚ÄúLange convinced her that the image would educate the public about the plight of hardworking but poor people like herself.‚Äù (paragraph 7)

C.Choice: ‚Äú... the photograph was a continual subject of conversation.‚Äù (paragraph 7)

D.Choice: ‚Äú'She always wanted a better life, you know.'‚Äù (paragraph 7)S

E.Choice: ‚ÄúShe had one of the most famous faces in the United States, yet, to keep her family together, she had to work 16 hours a day, seven days a week.‚Äù (paragraph 8)

F.Choice: ‚ÄúShe had posed for the photo to help others, not herself, ...‚Äù (paragraph 8)

SubTopics: Write narratives to develop experiences or events using effective literary techniques, well-chosen details, and well-structured sequences.

Apply knowledge of language to understand how language functions in different contexts, to make effective choices for meaning or style, and to comprehend more fully when reading or listening.
Content:
:ibox:For this question, you will write a narrative response based on the passage(s). Write your response in the space provided on the next two pages. Your writing should:

‚Ä¢ Use characters, settings, events, and other details from the passage(s).

‚Ä¢ Use correct grammar, spelling, and punctuation.

Be sure to use what you know about the characters, settings, and events from ùóïùó¢ùóßùóõ passages to develop your reflection.

SubTopics: Analyze in detail how an author's ideas or claims are developed and refined by particular sentences, paragraphs, or larger portions of a text (e.g., a section or chapter).
Content: Read the sentence from paragraph 13 of ‚ÄúWhen Mindfulness Meets the Classroom‚Äù in the box.

:box:A vast majority‚Äî97 percent‚Äîof students surveyed in 2014 said they would recommend the course to others, reporting benefits ranging from better sleep and diminished stress to increased focus on schoolwork.
Which sentence from ‚ÄúInstead of Detention‚Äù makes the same point?

A.Choice: ‚Äú'Some of them come to school from situations where they don't have lights at home, or food.'‚Äù (paragraph 8)

B.Choice: ‚ÄúThere, foundation staff members encourage them to talk about what led to their dismissal from class...‚Äù (paragraph 9)

C.Choice: ‚ÄúAlthough a meditation room is no miracle cure for students' strife, those at the school say it's done wonders for their learning environment and productivity.‚Äù (paragraph 13)

D.Choice: ‚ÄúAll children at Coleman start and end their school day with a 15-minute guided meditation over the intercom.‚Äù (paragraph 19)

Content: Read the sentence from paragraph 17 of ‚ÄúWhen Mindfulness Meets the Classroom‚Äù in the box.
:box:‚ÄúIf you don't address the noise in a kid's head that they bring in from the outside, I don't care how good a teacher you are, you're not going to have much success.‚Äù

A.Choice: ‚Äú'We have a few frequent fliers here,' Lee said.‚Äù (paragraph 12)

B.Choice: ‚Äú'When the kids come down here, they're all rowdy and goofing around,' ...‚Äù (paragraph 14)

C.Choice: ‚Äú'We aren't in a place yet where we can say that we know this works,' she said.‚Äù (paragraph 25)

Content: Read the sentence from paragraph 28 of ‚ÄúInstead of Detention‚Äù in the box.
:box:‚ÄúWhen we sit with pain or discomfort rather than act on it, we learn that feelings and sensations come and go.‚Äù
Which detail from ‚ÄúWhen Mindfulness Meets the Classroom‚Äù ùóïùóòùó¶ùóß supports the claim in the sentence?

A.Choice: ‚ÄúStill holding the bowl, Gonzalez continued with the day's lesson.‚Äù (paragraph 5)

B.Choice: ‚Äú'As you breathe in and breathe out, notice that your breath is going to be stronger in a certain part of your body.'‚Äù (paragraph 8)

C.Choice: ‚Äú'Maybe it's your belly, your chest, or your nose. We'll begin with trying to count to 10 breaths.'‚Äù (paragraph 8)

D.Choice: ‚Äú'If you get lost in thought, it's okay. Just come back and count again. Whether you get up to 10 or not doesn't really matter. It's just a way to focus [your] mind.'‚Äù (paragraph 10)
